facts.text: Order of detention made by District Magistrate, Bankura on 16-1-71.
Petitioner arrested on 20-1-71 and served with order and grounds of detention on the same day.
District Magistrate made report to State Government on 20-1-71, approved by State Government on 27-1-71.
Report made to Central Government on 27-1-71 under Section 3(5).
Detention order, grounds and report placed before Advisory Board on 18-2-71.
State Government rejected representation of detenue on 15-3-71.
Advisory Board submitted report on 23-3-71 that there was sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed Board's opinion on 8-4-71.
Communication of confirmation to detenue made on 26-8-71.
On 7-1-71 night, petitioner and associates mutilated statue of Rabindra Nath Tagore at Boilapara, Bishnupur.
On 11-1-71 at 01.45 hrs., petitioner and associates broke into Post Office at Rashikguni, Bishnupur, and destroyed records by fire.
Act upheld as constitutional in State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey Ors.

legal_issues.text: Whether the mandatory provisions of the Act have been complied with.
Whether the grounds of detention are irrelevant or vague.

Whether the State Government confirmed the opinion of the Advisory Board that there was sufficient cause for detention within three months from the date of detention and communicated it to the detenue within that period.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government must confirm the opinion of the Board within three months from date of detention and communicate such confirmation to the detenue within that period.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970 Sections 12, 13; Article 22(4)

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds are vague because associates not specified.
Acts specified disturb law and order, not public order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madhu Limaye v. Sub-Divisional Magistrate; Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar

respondent_arguments.text: No warrant in the Act or Article 22(4) for State Government to confirm Board's report within three months or communicate to detenue.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Dattatraya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay; Article 22(4)

respondent_arguments.text: Confirmation can be within reasonable time after Board's report.

court_reasoning.text: Confirmation of Board's opinion to continue detention beyond three months must be within three months from date of detention, in conformity with Article 22(4).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to confirm within three months renders detention illegal.

court_reasoning.text: Confirmation must be in writing, but communication to detenue need not be within three months; must be within reasonable time; no prejudice shown here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Communication delay is irregularity, not vitiating detention.

court_reasoning.text: In this case, all mandatory provisions complied with: detention 16/20-1-71, confirmation 8-4-71 within three months.
Grounds not vague: dates, times, acts specified; no need to name all associates.
Acts fall under Section 3(2)(c): insult to object of public veneration (statue); mischief to public property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prejudicial to maintenance of public order as per Act upheld in Ashok Dey.

holdings.text: State Government must confirm Advisory Board's opinion of sufficient cause within three months from detention date to extend beyond three months.
Confirmation order must be in writing and communicated to detenue within reasonable time, but not necessarily within three months.
In this case, detention is legal as all procedures complied with and grounds valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Act constitutional; Section 3(2)(c) valid for acts insulting public veneration objects.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dattatraya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with form of confirmation order and extension period, not timing.
Confirmation must be within three months.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhadhal Kanthad Valeg v. Saurashtra State
Sangappa Mallappa Kodli Ors. v. State of Mysore Ors.
Ashvini Kumar Banerjee v. State Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirmation under Section 12(1) within three months.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhu Limaye v. Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Monghyr
precedents_cited.relevance: Acts here affect public order per Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar
Biren Dutta Ors. v. Chief Commissioner of Tripura
precedents_cited.relevance: Decision to extend detention should be clear and communicated.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs detention procedures, grounds, Advisory Board reference, confirmation, maximum period.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandates Board report within three months for detention beyond three months; basis for habeas corpus.

outcome.summary: Court held that mandatory provisions fully complied with, confirmation within three months, grounds neither vague nor irrelevant but squarely covered under Section 3(2)(c). Detention legal; no merit in petition.

key_quotes.text: "the confirmation of the opinion of the Advisory Board to continue the detention beyond three months must be within three months from the date of detention in conformity with the mandate in clause 4 of Article 22."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on timing of confirmation.

key_quotes.text: "Though there is no provision in the Act an order of confirmation which has the effect of extending the period of detention beyond the mandatory period of three months must be made known to the detenue."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We think there is no validity in this submission. Not only the dates and the time in each of the grounds have been mentioned but the acts of the petitioner have been specified in detail."
key_quotes.speaker: court
